events.summary: Attorney General Pam Bondi has established the "weaponization working group" in response to an executive order from Donald Trump. This group, composed of various Justice Department offices, is tasked with reviewing potential abuses of the criminal justice system over the past four years. The group will report its findings to Stephen Miller, Trump's deputy chief of staff for policy, which raises concerns about the Justice Department's independence due to its direct reporting line to the White House. The group is also scrutinized for potential conflicts of interest, as some members have previously defended Trump or been involved in adversarial litigation against the Biden administration.

The pardons are seen as a signal that Trump supports those who commit crimes on his behalf, raising concerns about future acts of violence by far-right groups.

events.summary: The Pentagon announced plans to lay off 5,400 civilian workers, marking the start of a broader reduction of 5-8% of its civilian workforce. This move aligns with Donald Trump's political goals to institute massive government cuts. The layoffs will begin next week, targeting probationary employees who have been on the job for less than a year. The Department of Defense will also implement a hiring freeze to assess personnel needs. The cuts are part of a larger plan to potentially reduce up to 60,000 civilian positions within the department.

events.summary: The Trump administration has shut down the National Law Enforcement Accountability Database (NLEAD), which was created to track police misconduct and prevent officers with records of misconduct from moving undetected between agencies. The database, initially proposed by Trump in 2020 and established by the Biden administration in 2023, is no longer accessible. The U.S. Department of Justice confirmed the database's decommissioning, stating that user agencies can no longer query or add data to it. The decision to eliminate the database was part of Trump's broader effort to reduce federal agencies.

events.summary: The US Supreme Court declined to hear two cases challenging "buffer zone" ordinances that limit protests near abortion clinics. These ordinances, from Carbondale, Illinois, and Englewood, New Jersey, were argued by anti-abortion activists to violate the First Amendment's free speech protections. The activists sought to overturn the 2000 Hill v. Colorado ruling, which upheld similar laws. Justices Samuel Alito and Clarence Thomas expressed a desire to revisit the Hill decision, but the court did not provide reasons for declining the cases. The ordinances remain in effect, maintaining restrictions on protest activities near clinics.
events.title: US Supreme Court declines to hear anti-abortion buffer zone cases
